_prev_prog_3.Description:
Chevron views the health and safety of its employees and the communities in which it operates as its top priority.  On a global scale, Chevron has implemented its Operational Excellence (OE) process that establishes the standards by which all Chevron business units must operate.  Guided by the Chevron OE process, the Doraville terminal has implemented a robust OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program to protect its people, the local community, and the integrity of process equipment.  The following sections will provide an overview of the various elements of the terminal's PSM program.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The cornerstone of the PSM program is Process Safety Information. Process Safety Information defines the chemical hazards, equipment, and technology in a given process. The terminal maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the butane blending process. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters including specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis and configuration information. Specific individuals are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.  Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards, emergency response and exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). The terminal has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters and ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls, instrumentation monitoring, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).  The terminal also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provide a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The terminal has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, processes are systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The terminal primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience, as well as expertise in systems control technology and engineering.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.



The PHA team findings are reviewed and assigned to individuals and work groups for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest riskreceive priority attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and the documentation is retained.  To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the terminal periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These reviews include not only the original study data, but they include process changes in the last five years that have been made through the MOC process and a review of incidents both in the unit and in other similar units throughout industry. Periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years until the process is no longer operational. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.



OPERATING PROCEDURES

The terminal maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) process startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, and (5) normal shutdown.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are reviewed and certified annually as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change (MOC) process.



TRAINING

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Chevron and the terminal have implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in process operations and, after successfully completing this training, are paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. Operators are allowed to work independently only after demonstrating, through tests and/or various skill demonstrations, that they possess adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The terminal has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.  Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or an MOC team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.  Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The terminal incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The terminal has a comprehensive system to manage changes to its processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary additional training on the change.



PRE-STARTUP REVIEW

The terminal conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) for any new process or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, such as, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of process startup readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the terminal will periodically conduct a compliance audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three (3) years or more often if facility changes require further review. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to terminal management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS

The terminal promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or potentially could result in, a fire or explosion, major property damage, environmental release, or personal injury. All incidents that result in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a highly hazardous chemical in the workplace must be investigated as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours following the incident. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation teams include personnel who are knowledgeable in the process involved in the incident, contract employees if work involved a contractor, and other employees with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze an incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to terminal management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five (5) years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The facility encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information generated from the terminal accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the terminal and addresses each accident prevention program element. In addition, the terminal has a number of initiatives that address process safety and employee safety issues. These initiatives include forming committees to promote both process and personal safety. The committees typically have members from various areas of the terminal, including operations, maintenance, engineering, and terminal management.



HOT WORK PERMITS

The terminal maintains a Work Permit Program to promote safe work practices for ensuring worker and process safety. Permits are required before any spark-producing activities (hot work) can be conducted at the facility. Furthermore, an additional permit is required before entry into a confined space is allowed to ensure that adequate precautions and evacuation measures are in place prior to confined space entry. Various other safe work practice policies and procedures are utilized to facilitate safe operations. Examples of these include, but are not limited to, the following:



- Control of the entry, presence and exit of support personnel from the process unit;

- A lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance; and

- A procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened.



These and other procedures, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



CONTRACTORS

The terminal utilizes contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the terminal has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:

(1) Perform their work in a safe manner;

(2) Have the appropriate knowledge and skills to execute their assigned task;

(3) Are aware of the hazards in their workplace;

(4) Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency;

(5) Understand and follow site safety rules; and

(6) Inform terminal management of any hazards that they find during their work.



This is accomplished by providing contractors with each of the following:

(1) A process overview;

(2) Information about safety and health hazards;

(3) Emergency response plan requirements; and

(4) Training on safe work practices prior to beginning work.



To ensure a safe work environment, the terminal evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during contractor selection. Additionally, terminal personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE

The terminal maintains a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP), which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the terminal has developed procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  As part of the butane blending project, manual deluge systems are being installed to aid in emergency response. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The ERP is updated when necessary based on modifications made to terminal processes or operations. The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.



The overall emergency response program for the terminal is coordinated with the local fire department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which are attended by local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. The terminal has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the terminal conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the terminal provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances at the terminal.

Chevron Downstream & Chemicals - Doraville, Georgia Americas Products Terminal

Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary



The Chevron Downstream & Chemicals - Doraville, Georgia Americas Products Terminal (the "terminal") is located at 4026 Winters Chapel Road; Doraville, Dekalb County, Georgia 30360.  The terminal is a petroleum bulk terminal storing gasoline, diesel fuel, and fuel ethanol.  Gasoline and diesel fuel are received at this facility via Plantation Pipeline and Colonial Pipeline from the Gulf Coast.  Gasoline Additives, Diesel Additive, and Fuel Ethanol are received at the terminal by way of tank trucks.  The terminal also has the capability of receiving petroleum products by tank trucks.  All petroleum products are stored at this facility in aboveground tanks and loaded into tank trucks.  Off-specification product (Transmix) is also stored at the facility until it can be returned for recycling. All petroleum products are distributed from this facility by way of tank trucks.



Chevron DS&C has a butane blending process at the terminal to inject butane into its gasoline immediately prior to truck loading of various gasoline products.  The terminal receives butane via tanker trucks and stores the butane in one (1) 60,000-gallon pressurized horizontal butane storage vessel.  The butane blending operation and associated butane storage render the terminal subject to 40 CFR 68 requirements.  Moreover, this operation renders the terminal subject to the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) - Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, codified in 29 CFR ?1910.119.  As such, the terminal is subject to RMP Prevention Program 3 requirements.



Chevron and the terminal have a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety, which is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Ou

r policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and/or notify the necessary outside agencies.



WORST-CASE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SCENARIO



The 60,000-gallon storage vessel at the facility carries a flammable mixture consisting of normal butane, isobutane, isopentane, hexane, olefins, normal pentane, and propane.  The flammable mixture possesses physical characteristics of a NFPA No. 4 flammable material and the weight percentages of each constituent vary; therefore, for modeling purposes, it is assumed that the entire weight of the flammable mixture is normal butane.  It should be noted that an analysis was also performed using the other constituents in the flammable mixture but the resulting endpoint distance was no greater using any of these constituents either as the entire weight of the flammable mixture or in varying percentages. The facility utilizes administrative controls to not allow the vessel to be filled beyond eighty (80) percent capacity; therefore, the storage volume of the vessel is 48,000 gallons.  In addition, according to the process safety information an estimated 607 gallons of the flammable mixture may be contained in process piping and associated appurtenances, and this quantity is also included in the worst-case release scenario as these may rupture in the event of a catastrophic release.  Therefore, the maximum storage capacity of this flammable mixture in the 60,000-gallon storage vessel, process piping, and associated appurtenances for the worst-case flammable release scenario taking into account administrative controls is estimated at 239,175.6 pounds (48,607 gallons), assuming a specific gravity of 0.59 for the flammable mixture.



The latitude and longitude of the storage vessel are 33? 54' 40.842" North (33.911345?) and 84? 16' 19.3836" West (-84.27

2051?), respectively.  The flammable mixture is stored as a liquid under pressure, and the catastrophic failure (worst-case scenario) of the storage vessel and the subsequent vapor cloud explosion results in an endpoint distance of 0.5 miles (0.8 kilometers). 

The United States Census Bureau's (USCB) Landview 6 population estimating software was utilized to estimate the population impacted by this accidental release.  This worst-case scenario has the potential to impact an estimated population of 1,725 people (549 residences).  No schools or hospitals were identified within the impact area; however, Hightower Elementary, to the North, is just outside the impact area.  Additionally, within the impact area are a farmer's market and shopping center to the South, as well as multiple industrial facilities.  No sensitive environmental receptors were identified as potentially being affected by the worst-case release scenario. 



ALTERNATIVE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SCENARIO



As a RMP Prevention Program 3 facility, the facility is required to submit one alternative release scenario for an accidental flammable release.  A possible alternative flammable release scenario is a release at the butane unloading area as a result of a truck accidentally pulling away while still connected or a hose misconnection or malfunction during the unloading operation.  This scenario was identified as a possibility in the process hazards analysis for the butane blending process.  The butane released could potentially ignite due to an engine spark and could cause the butane truck being unloaded to catch fire or reach a critical temperature, eventually resulting in a boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE).  The BLEVE scenario yields a more conservative endpoint distance than that of a flash fire or vapor cloud fire thus the BLEVE was selected as the alternative scenario.



In the event of a flash fire or vapor cloud fire, this BLEVE alternative scenario should be referred to when assessin

g evacuation areas and potential offsite impacts.  For the BLEVE alternative scenario, the butane tanker truck is conservatively assumed to be carrying 9,000 gallons (44,285.5 pounds) of the butane flammable mixture.  The endpoint distance calculated as a result of this release is 0.3 miles (0.4 kilometers).  The latitude and longitude of this alternative scenario are 33? 54' 37.4328" North (33.910398?) and 84? 16' 16.374" West (-84.271215?), respectively.



The USCB Landview 6 population estimating software was utilized to estimate the population impacted by this accidental release.  This alternative scenario has the potential to impact an estimated population of 4 people (2 residences).  In the event of a release of this magnitude, the facility will make every effort to verify that the impacted area has been evacuated.  Furthermore, Landview 6 does not take into account commercial or industrial receptors in its population estimates; thus, the facility should notify all neighboring businesses and industrial complexes in the event of this accidental release scenario.  No sensitive environmental receptors were identified as potentially being affected by this alternative scenario.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 



Chevron views the health and safety of its employees and the communities in which it operates as its top priority.  On a global scale, Chevron has implemented its Operational Excellence (OE) process that establishes the standards by which all Chevron business units must operate.  Guided by the Chevron OE process, the Doraville terminal has implemented a robust OSHA PSM program to protect its people, the local community, and the integrity of process equipment.  Refer to Section 7 of this RMP submission for a detailed discussion of the terminal's OSHA PSM program. 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



At the time of this RMP submission, there are no RMP-related accidents to be reported since no RMP-substances were stored at the facility until t

he butane blending process became operational.

In addition, the terminal has developed procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The ERP is updated when necessary based on modifications made to terminal processes or operations. This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which are attended by local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The terminal has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC

meetings, the terminal conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the terminal provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances at the terminal.
